div.p: Greetings. I send you (reverend father) the first part of the Response, which was produced by the first impulse; what I send is not yet polished, I only seek your judgment.
I have been writing all day, and now it is late at night, and I am completely exhausted.
Therefore, I have not distinguished everything well, and many things are also lacking in composition.
The second part remains, which will be entirely didactic; for every question will be about the church, the perfection, clarity, and certainty of scripture.
I intend to compare with scripture the traditions, councils, fathers, popes, and also the authority of the church in general.
You see how wide a field presents itself; but either it must be silent or these things must be handled.

Once these are completed, I will briefly compare the papal doctrine with the holy scriptures, which you also once did; I will add a few things about ecclesiastical judgments; for the absurdity of the papal doctrine is so great that it now falls into the eyes of all.
Finally, I will turn to the Germans, and just as Fontidonius praises the benefits of the popes, so I will remind them of their misdeeds.

When I will complete these, I cannot yet determine. If you have anything beyond what is in your commentaries and in the Apocalypse about the deceit of the popes towards the German princes, please, note it.
I have also collected some ridiculous and inept formulas of the papists for interpreting scriptures, of which I know you have an abundance.
I send these now to use your judgment. You will say I am too vehement; but consider with whom I have business.

When you read these at leisure (the matter easily suffers delay), I wish to know from you whether they can be printed in ZÃ¼rich, which I would very much like due to the proximity of the place; but if not and you do not wish to involve yourselves in my fire, let me know this too, so that I can promptly look for a printer, while those good fathers still reside in Trento.
In all things, I will acquiesce to your judgment.
But I ask you, do not, out of your singular modesty, order me to be too modest as well.
I know with what danger I undertake all these things, and God is my witness that I would have preferred to rest.
But what can I do? I am dragged by the hair, I cannot do otherwise.
The rascals know who I am, they know the place where I dwell; but because they pretend, they have given it to our bishop, so that he himself does not seem to be the torch of this fire.
Forgive me, reverend father, for writing so tumultuously; I cannot do otherwise, my hand is exhausted. Farewell.
Chur, on the same day as before, or rather in the dead of night, in the year 1563.
Yours observantly, Johannes Fabricius.
You will return this first part of the speech through suitable people; for my copy is covered with erasures.
These very things are now given to me by Mr. Ulrich Martinengi; I barely glanced at them; you will return them sometime.
To the most esteemed Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and father in Christ, to be eternally revered.
